#Text=Understand and Respect Chinese Superstitions
#Text=China is home to many diverse and ancient cultures , thus Chinese people traditionally have certain superstitions .
#Text=When in China or interacting with Chinese culture , it is best to learn and understand these superstitions to avoid offending people .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Numbers
#Text=Avoid the number 4 whenever possible .
#Text=四(four ) is pronounced si ( 四 sì ( si ) [ ssuh ] - like a snake with ' uh ' ( say the vowel in the back of your throat ) ) .
#Text=The word for " death " 死 is pronounced si ( with falling intonation ) .

column1: #Text=Because of the similarities in pronunciation , the Chinese avoid anything to do with 4 .
#Text=Some buildings may " lack " a fourth floor .
#Text=Avoid giving gifts in sets of four .
#Text=Some more modern buildings may also lack a thirteenth floor , having adopted the Western superstitions .
#Text=Celebrate eight .
#Text=In contrast , the number 8 is considered extremely auspicious .
#Text=It is associated with wealth .
#Text=Gift Giving
#Text=Avoid giving anyone ( particularly the elderly ) clocks .
#Text=The Chinese word for clock 钟 ( zhong1 ) is pronounced exactly the same as the word for end 终 .
#Text=Giving a clock as a gift in Chinese culture is the equivalent of wishing death upon someone .
#Text=Avoid offering pears to close friends .
#Text=The Chinese word for pear 梨 ( li2 ) is pronounced the same as 离 , meaning to leave .
#Text=Giving pears to friends is considered bad luck , as it is considered an omen for the end of your friendship .
#Text=Avoid giving shoes to friends or significant others .
#Text=Giving shoes implies that you want them to walk out of your life .
#Text=Colors
#Text=When in doubt , wear or use red .
#Text=Red is an auspicious color in Chinese culture .
#Text=Avoid giving white gifts , or gifts wrapped in white .
#Text=Unlike in the West , where black signifies death , China uses white for the same purpose .
#Text=Chinese New Year
#Text=Celebrate with noise .
#Text=Fireworks were used in ancient times to frighten bad spirits .
#Text=Fireworks in China , particularly 鞭炮 , are loud .
#Text=These are used during holidays like 春节 ( Chinese New Year ) to frighten away spirits who would bring bad luck .
#Text=Clean out the old .
#Text=Cleaning during the New Year will bring good luck .
#Text=You essentially " sweep out " the old .
#Text=Eat fish on 除夕 but leave some leftovers .
#Text=Chinese has a saying " 年年有鱼 , 年年有余 " , meaning that if you have fish every year , then every year you 'll have surplus ; however , you need to leave surplus in order for this work .
#Text=Hang 福 upside down on your door or in your house .
#Text=The word 福 ( fu2 ) means happiness or prosperity .
#Text=By hanging it upside down ( 倒 dao ) then 福 will arrive ( 到 dao ) .
#Text=Pregnancy and Birth
#Text=Learn the interactions between superstitions and pregnancy/birth :
#Text=During pregnancy , women must be very careful about what animals they interact with .
#Text=The presence of some animals is said to influence the characteristics of their baby .
#Text=Women avoid cutting their hair during pregnancy and after birth .
#Text=Some women believe it will affect the life expectancy of the child .
#Text=Many Chinese families will plan their child 's birth to coincide with certain years .
#Text=Every year is represented by a different Chinese zodiac animal .
#Text=Most often , people will aim for the year of the Dragon or Pig and avoid the year of the Sheep .
#Text=Miscellaneous
#Text=Eat noodles to celebrate .
#Text=On birthdays , Chinese people eat a special kind of noodle .
#Text=These noodles are very long , symbolizing longevity .
#Text=Understand feng shui .
#Text=Feng shui 风水 is the Chinese art of balance .
#Text=Homes , businesses ( and originally graves ) are designed in certain ways to maximize benefit and maintain an overall balance of qi .
#Text=Avoid facing beds near doors .
#Text=Certain locations are associated with certain elements .
#Text=Avoid clutter , which disrupts the flow of qi .
